title: Major Scale
description: Start by picking which key you want to play. Then, focus on playing it in the first position (see image below). Focus on clean notes and smooth transitions. Try to focus on alternate picking and make sure you are using the correct fingers.

title: Minor pentatonic Scale
description: Start by picking which key you want to play. Then, focus on playing it in the first position (see image below). Focus on clean notes and smooth transitions. Try to focus on alternate picking and make sure you are using the correct fingers.

title: Chord Transitions
description: Choose a chord progression and practice transitioning between chords smoothly and accurately. Start with single down strokes and focus on staying on the beat.

title: Quickfire Exercise 1: The Chromatic Climb
description: A fundamental finger independence exercise. Play the 1-2-3-4 pattern on each string, focusing on clean articulation and staying in sync with a metronome. Start slow (e.g., 60 BPM).

title: Quickfire Exercise 2: The Chromatic Descent
description: Reverse the previous pattern by playing 4-3-2-1. This builds strength in the pinky and dexterity in descending lines. Ensure each note rings clearly.

title: Quickfire Exercise 3: Chromatic Position Shifts (Ascending)
description: Play the 1-2-3-4 pattern, but shift your hand position up by one fret after each sequence (e.g., 1-2-3-4, then 2-3-4-5). Improves fretboard navigation.

title: Quickfire Exercise 4: Chromatic Position Shifts (Descending)
description: Play the 4-3-2-1 pattern, shifting your hand position up by one fret after each sequence (e.g., 4-3-2-1, then 5-4-3-2).

title: Quickfire Exercise 5: Linear Chromatic Ascent
description: Perform the 1-2-3-4 pattern moving horizontally across the fretboard on a single string, or shifting positions rapidly. Focus on smooth transitions between positions.

title: Quickfire Exercise 6: Linear Chromatic Descent
description: Perform the 4-3-2-1 pattern moving horizontally, shifting positions up the neck. Maintains coordination while changing hand positions.

title: Quickfire Exercise 7: Finger Permutation (1-3-2-4)
description: A 'twisted' chromatic variation. Instead of 1-2-3-4, play fingers 1, 3, 2, then 4. This breaks muscle memory and improves individual finger control.

title: Quickfire Exercise 8: Finger Permutation (4-2-3-1)
description: The descending version of the twisted pattern. Play fingers 4, 2, 3, then 1. Great for pinky independence and mental agility.

title: Quickfire Exercise 9: Permutation Shifts (Ascending)
description: Apply the 1-3-2-4 permutation pattern while shifting positions up the neck. Focus on maintaining the tricky finger order while moving your hand.

title: Quickfire Exercise 10: Permutation Shifts (Descending)
description: Apply the 4-2-3-1 permutation pattern while shifting positions. Challenges both your finger independence and position shifting accuracy.

title: Quickfire Exercise 11: Wide Intervals (Ascending)
description: Uses fingers 1, 3, and 4 (or 1, 2, 3 for a stretch) to play a 1-3-5 pattern (e.g., frets 1, 3, 5). Focuses on stretching the fingers and covering wider intervals.

title: Quickfire Exercise 12: Wide Intervals (Descending)
description: The reverse of the wide interval pattern (5-3-1). Requires control to reach back accurately without muting adjacent strings.

title: Quickfire Exercise 13: Wide Interval Shifts (Ascending)
description: Play the 1-3-5 wide pattern and shift the entire shape up the fretboard (e.g. 1-3-5, 2-4-6). Builds strength in maintaining a stretched hand shape.

title: Quickfire Exercise 14: Wide Interval Shifts (Descending)
description: Play the 5-3-1 wide pattern and shift the shape up the fretboard. Maintains the stretch while navigating the neck.

title: Quickfire Exercise 15: Hammer-on Mechanics
description: Focus on the 'Hammer-on' (H) technique. Use fingers 1 & 3, then 2 & 4. Pick the first note and hammer the second firmly to ensure equal volume.

title: Quickfire Exercise 16: Ascending Legato Runs
description: Play 3-note-per-string scales using hammer-ons (e.g., pick 3, hammer 5, hammer 7). Focus on smooth, flowing sound without picking every note.

title: Quickfire Exercise 17: Advanced Interval Study
description: A combination of wide intervals (1-3-5 pattern) played across multiple strings or shifting positions. Can be played with strict alternate picking.

title: Quickfire Exercise 18: Downstroke Picking
description: Focus strictly on downstrokes (indicated by the Î  symbol). This builds picking hand stamina and rhythmic consistency. Do not alternate pick.

title: Quickfire Exercise 19: Pull-off Mechanics
description: Focus on 'Pull-offs' (P). Pick the high note and pull off to the lower ones. Also includes slides (/). Keep the pull-off snappy to maintain volume.

title: Quickfire Exercise 20: Hammer-on & Pull-off Combo
description: Develops skill in alternating between hammer-ons and pull-offs. Use the hammering finger to pluck the string for the subsequent pull-off.
